snippet: Advocates say that New York's former archbishop reopened wounds in a new interview in which he said that he never should have apologized for the church's handling of the sex-abuse crisis and that no abuse had occurred on his watch.
abstract: Advocates say that New York's former archbishop reopened wounds in a new interview in which he said that he never should have apologized for the church's handling of the sex-abuse crisis and that no abuse had occurred on his watch.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, at the height of the outcry over the sexual abuse of minors by Roman Catholic priests, the Archbishop of New York, Edward M. Egan, issued a letter to be read at Mass. In it, he offered an apology about the church's handling of sex-abuse cases in New York and in Bridgeport, Conn., where he was previously posted.

headline.main: Cardinal Egan Criticized for Retracting Apology on Sexual Abuse Crisis
